reviewText: Seems like a real gem of an indie game. Personality and care in design seem to be dripping off it, despite some meh voice acting (to be expected in the indie scene though). Too bad it refuses to run in full screen, no matter how much I play with the graphical settings of both the game and my computer. The icons render too itty bitty to read, and the game is essentially unplayable.\n\nThis is a apparently a problem with my monitor, in the sense that my monitor uses tech that is more advanced than what the game supports. But even when I scale my monitor's resolution down to 1024x768 and adjust the game's settings to match it, the game window just gets smaller and smaller. I get the best results keeping the monitor at 3200x1800 and running the game at 1900x1080, but even then it still takes up just a third of the screen. Probably a problem unique to my particular monitor, but unfortunate that I don't get to enjoy the game as intended, and I just wanted to put that out there as a potential warning, even if it is an unlikely one. The game still gets a recommendation on spirit alone.

reviewText:
All aspects of the game are wonderful, made with thoughtful complexity. Strategic phase where/when you place traps, simple skill tree and some various items that nevertheless push character in the direction of your prefered playstyle, and combat phase where your strategic planning unfold, all are beautifully interwoven into great game of quite unique genre.

And what makes you constantly motivated throughout the game are new strategic elements that evolve step by step till the end.

Its a shame that such a great game got so untalented actors and dialog writer.
Another downside of the game is that it doesnt have other play mode than the story play mode which is quite short.

If you like making strategic solutions, timed 3rd person hack and slash alike action with a scent of rpg then this is the game you will enjoy.

9/10

reviewText:
Now, THIS is what I call a good game!

You see, a big part of a game can be decided by it's first impression. Some games do it wrong and plaster your face with 3rd party launchers past Steam and a ton of logos.
When I started Sang-Froid, I was instantly welcomed with a plain loading screen accompanied by the single best intro theme I've heard in months, if not years. Not kidding, I was actually disappointed when the game finished loading and the song got cut off, so much I actually went and found myself the full into song online.

However, after the intro song + narration I was sure I had a neat game at my hands and I wasn't disappointed: Whilst the graphic and animations certainly aren't worthy of an AAA title (and there are a couple animation errors all across the game), they provide exactly the charme the intro already emitted. Overall, a really nice part of the game is it's atmosphere: You indeed feel like playing in the later colonial era, a time filled with issues of belief, mystic and tales. Except for the horrible facial models, everything the game shows and tells you feels really authentic.

Of course we are here to play a game though, not check on a visua novel, so how's the gameplay?
Intriguing, to say the least. The early days start out really simple. Go there, shoot that wolf, axe those other wolves some questions. Quickly you learn that any enemy group with more then two enemies means certain death if you don't fight with a brain (and an eye on your stamina gauge).
But as the day progresses, so does your equipment, your character and, of course, the enemies, both in quality and number.
On daytime, you get the next bit of the story and place traps and other devices. As soon as the sun falls, you run around, trigger the traps and defend up to 5 locations at once. Impossible you say? A nice challenge, I say, given the game has a really fair difficulty curve (and an additional 'difficulty setting' in form of two character, with one being clearly weaker then the other and advertised as 'hard mode').

Overall, Sang-Froid is exactly the kind of great game I would wish every indie title would be.
Though, there IS a little catch: The game has no replayability value. At best, you will go and play it twice, assuming you started with the easier character (I didn't, and are welcoming the difficulty. Albeit this cuts my potential playtime in half.) I'm currently 2/3rds through the game in mere 4 hours.
This feels a tad short, especially if you got to consider the base 15€ price. I personally purchased it in the 90% off deal and therefore are HIGHLY pleased with the price-playtime ration.

Judgement: 9/10 (Can't give it a 10, even though not gamebreaking, those animation glitches ARE annoying at times)
Must-buy if on sale and on 5€ or less.

reviewText:
Despite the rough graphics and voice-acting, despite the hack & slash being lacking, it blends together with a rich atmosphere, capable RPG elements and ingenious strategic compentents to come together as a deeply clever and immersive game that has no equals in a genre it has created all by itself: Which I'd like to call Strategic Action Defense.


In essence, the game is a unique, ingenious bland between a rudimentary third person hack&slash and a clever (tower) defense game in the most strategic sense possible. Anyone would be excused for thinking of isometric Multiplayer Online Battle Arena (MOBA) games like LOL or DOTA, or Orcs Must Die where the combat is hectic, constant, fast paced and deals with hundreds of mindless mobs marching towards your side, but Sang-Froid is not. Instead the action is tense, tactical, clever and far more personal.

Every game, you start off with a top down perspective of a pine forest through which snowy trails wind towards your cabin. They're paths taken by an onslaught of wolves out to tear it down. This is the planning phase. At first, you just need to defend the cabin where your sick sister lies, but soon the barn, mill, church and more buildings get added to the community under your care. Your sister is a special kind of sick however. She can see from where the wolves are coming to attack those buildings and what routes they'll take, through visions.

This is where the first difference between the game and others like it become apparant: It's personal. When you choose to leave the planning stage and enter the world, the third person hack&slash ensures that your character is the most versatile weapon you have and there really aren't that many wolves, especially in the beginning. Its just that the wolves are capable of coming in from anywhere and your character is just one man with a tiny bar of stamina that can't possibly cover the large stretches of space between buildings AND safely fight more than a few wolves at the same time. And when you do choose to engage, the wolves aren't fodder either. They really are characters in their own right.

Personal combat is involving. Should they have all pounced at once, they would have torn you apart, but a complex system of fear and intimidation, using roars, fires and actions, will see them circling while you deal with those few who manage the courage to take swipes at you. You are are armed with axe and rifle, but the axe will quickly sap your stamina and your rifle is an antique that requires 10 seconds of loading. Tougher foes arrive by themselves or in pairs, but these are often so durable that they take just as much time as any one of those packs.
Combat is a long process against worthy foes then, but time isn't something you have as more packs all over the map close in on your buildings.

This is where the traps come in, and a good deal of patience and savvy from you. Using the planning phase ahead of the third person action phase, allows you to not only prepare your own community through the purchase of gear, but to prepare a strategy for dealing with all of these packs at the same time. And instead of just placing down towers that splash the occasional damage, these traps are of the visceral, personal kind, suited to dealing with a foe that would have given you so much trouble in melee.

Bearclaws will instantly kill the four legged wolves. Bait attracts and slows them down, giving you precious extra time. Placing nets with an avalanche of rocks in them high among the treetops, will bury werewolves when timed right. Place kindle in certain passages and set it alight to redirect packs.
Some of these traps work automatic. Others are far more involving. The net trap for example, needs to be triggered by a shot from your rifle, preferably after luring the werewolf underneath through the use of deception: Bait or a shout to lure it there.

If there's one thing the game does exceedingly well, it is to establish the relationship between hunter and hunted, or making you feel like a rugged outdoors man triumphing over nature through wit. You are keenly aware of just how frightful and tough a werewolf can be in combat, so seeing it carried off through the air on the sharp tip of a ballista bolt after you've personally set it off and tricked the wolf in the right position is a gleeful moment. The transfer between planning phase where you control the map, and action phase where your control is limited to the range of your gun is a disempowering one. The map is tidy, but on foot, the mill is a world away. All you could do is set some spike traps around it, only to realize you couldn't do the same for the werewolf you are about to face for lack of cash. There's only a bonfire for him, to keep him back. Will it work?" You will wonder.

In such a moment
date: a sudden swish-click-yelp sound in the far distance of the frozen wintersky
recommended:
will make you smile as you keep warm around the lit bonfire.


Other than this

The mythology of werewolves and Canadian folklore is handled with careful respect and soon you'll be facing creatures from both British Canadian Christian fables and Native American Folklore. Even items are carefully described for their history in logging and Canadian history. I don't even mind the completely outdated method of clicking on individual buildings when going to town to buy gear. It adds to charm. The sound and music make up for a lot and once you manage to see past the outdated looks

reviewText:
http://lantredugeek.com/pc-sang-froid-un-conte-de-loups-garous/

Qu'est-ce que ce jeu?

Le principe de base de Sang-Froid est assez simple; les deux frères devront protéger leur sœur contre les hordes de monstres que le diable leur envoie la nuit. Pour ce faire, ils devront utiliser l'environnement qui les entoure à leur avantage et préparer de savants pièges et outils qui leur permettront de tenir une nuit de plus. Passons au travers des quelques éléments qui constituent ce magnifique jeu;



http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zK0yF8EDGlA&hd=1



Les deux frères / niveaux de difficulté

SangFroid_Feuille-PersonnageEn commençant votre partie, vous aurez le choix de jouer l'un des deux frères (Jacques Ti-Jack" et Joseph "Ti-Jos" O'Carroll). Les deux frères représentant les deux niveaux de difficulté du jeu; Facile/Difficile. En jouant avec Jacques O'Carroll (le mode difficile)
date: vous serez un chasseur agile et rusé. Vous devrez faire preuve d'ingéniosité à l'aide de vos trappes et de votre fusil de chasse
recommended: étant plus faible physiquement que votre autre frère
hoursPlayed: la ruse sera votre meilleure arme! En jouant avec Joseph O'Carroll (le mode facile)
voteText: vous serez un fier bûcheron fort et robuste. Vos coups de hache seront forts et puissants
helpfulPercent: il est également important de remarquer vous aurez beaucoup plus de facilité à résister aux attaques de vos ennemis. Les deux personnages auront accès aux mêmes actions
votesHelpful: objets et arbres de compétences. Cependant
votesTotal: les différences se joueront au niveau de la résistance physique
votesFunny: de la force de frappe avec la hache
commentsCount: de la précision aux armes à feu ainsi que l'agilité de chaque personnage. Tandis que l'un sera beaucoup plus résistant
column16: l'autre devra garder ses distances. Et alors que l'un possède une meilleure maîtrise de l'arme à feu
column17:
l'autre devra se préférer l'utilisation de sa fidèle hache.



La phase de préparations (le jour)

SangFroid_Jour-MonstresLe jour
column18: c'est votre période de préparation. Vous aurez accès à une carte détaillée de l'environnement dans lequel vous allez combattre. Sur ladite carte régionale
column19: vous aurez la possibilité de voir des cartes de monstre vous permettant de planifier vos défenses grâce aux prédictions de votre petite sœur
column20: Joséphine. Ces cartes vous permettront de connaître chaque type de monstre
column21: l'endroit d'où ceux-ci débuteront leur attaque
column22: leur trajectoire ainsi que leur but final. Une mission se déroule généralement sur deux tours (ou plus)
column23:
les prévisions de Joséphine vous permettront également de connaître d'avance l'ordre d’apparition des monstres pour chaque tour.

SangFroid_Jour-Trappes

Pour vous défendre contre les monstres
column24: vous aurez la possibilité de placer des pièges de toutes sortes pour vous aider dans votre tâche; appâts pour ralentir certaines créatures
column26: murs de feu pour changer la trajectoire de vos ennemis
column28: et plus encore! Chaque monstre possède ses faiblesses
column29: et ce sera votre travail de savoir quels pièges sont les plus appropriés aux situations dans lesquelles vous vous retrouverez. Pour installer un piège ou une installation
column30: vous devriez utiliser vos sous ainsi que vos points d'action. Après un certain point dans le jeu
column31: vous serez dans la mesure d'échanger vos points d'action contre des sous supplémentaires en coupant du bois.\n\nSangFroid_Magasin-GeneralPendant la préparation de vos défenses pour la nuit
column32: vous aurez également la chance de visiter le village de Val-aux-loups afin de faire quelques emplettes aux différents magasins du village. Vous pourrez y acheter armes
column33: balles pour vos armes à feu
column35: etc. Afin de pouvoir faire vos achats
column36: vous devrez utiliser les sous que vous aurez amassé au courant de vos dernières aventures. (Vous aurez des sous pour chaque monstre que vous aurez tué
column38: ou bien en vendant du bois.)\n\nUne fois que vous êtes préparés
column39:
il ne vous reste plus qu'à attendre que la nuit se lève.



La phase de combat (la nuit)

SangFroid_NuitEt la nuit
column40: c'est là que l'action commence! Vous aurez un petit laps de temps pour déplacer votre personnage là où vous le souhaitez avant que la première vague d'attaque ne commence. Par la suite
column41: vous devrez vous assurer que chaque créature a bien été tuée pour sauter à l'étape suivante. Pour ce faire
column42: vous pourrez activer certaines trappes manuellement (pièges de roches suspendues
column44: etc.) ou bien attaquer les créatures directement à l'aide de votre hache et de votre fusil.\n\nEn combat
column46: faire des roulades pour esquiver les attaques
column47: lancer de puissants cris pour attirer les créatures au loin ou effrayer les créatures tentant de vous attaquer
column48: attaquer vos ennemis à coups de hache
column50: utiliser les objets que vous aurez achetés au magasin ou même tomber en rage quelques secondes afin d'asséner des coups encore plus puissants aux monstres qui veulent votre peau. Faites attention à votre barre d'énergie; chaque fois que vous faites une action physique (coup de hache
column54: vous utiliserez une certaine quantité d'énergie. Une fois la barre vidée
column56: et deviendrez une proie facile. Il est important de prendre de petites pauses lorsqu'il est possible pour éviter que cela n'arrive!\n\nUne fois que vous aurez anéanti toutes les vagues de monstres
column57: vous aurez complété la mission. Vos récompenses en sous vous seront alors distribuées
column58:
et vous pourrez attaquer le prochain jour pour de nouveaux défis. Il est important de noter que chaque nuit apporte de nouveaux monstres ou de nouvelles possibilités/mécaniques de jeu qui vous demanderont de pouvoir vous adapter rapidement.



Qualité graphique
column60: les graphismes du jeu ne sont pas les plus beaux
column62: même si vos paramètres sont au maximum. Les modèles utilisés pour représenter les personnages et les créatures font un boulot très convenable et du moins
column63: le jeu n'est pas laid. L'ambiance générale et le style artistique de Sang-Froid nous permettent d'oublier très facilement les quelques lacunes côté modélisation
column64:
textures et animations.

SangFroid_Discussions

Malgré le style artistique intéressant de Sang-Froid
column65: le jeu possède une grosse lacune côté doublage. Malgré le fait que les voix francophones utilisent un français d'antan (ce qui facilite l'immersion d'ailleurs)
column66: nous avons l'impression que les acteurs lisent directement un livre sans regarder l'animation des personnages. Également
column67: il est important de noter qu'il n'y a pas beaucoup de cinématiques dans le jeu
column68: le jeu utilisant plus ou moins le même principe que les jeux de "nouvelles interactives" où l'image des personnages est placée au-dessus d'une boîte de texte. Seule différence est que chaque texte est accompagné d'une voix
column69:
et que l'image est remplacée par un modèle 3D quelque peu animé.



Conclusion

Sang-Froid est la preuve que le Québec est capable de grandes choses dans le monde du jeu vidéo. Le petit studio indépendant d'Artifice Studios a su créer un petit bijou que tous les amateurs de jeux de stratégie devraient se procurer. L'univers utilisé pour le jeu est unique et utilise une époque peu exploitée par l'industrie
column70: ce qui lui donne un charme exceptionnel. La qualité graphique du jeu est un peu basse
column71: mais le style artistique de celui-ci nous fait rapidement oublier ces quelques lacunes. Le jeu ne possède pas de modes multijoueurs
column72:
mais offre tout de même un excellent facteur plaisir. Nous vous conseillons de vous le procurer dès maintenant!

UNIVERS/CONSISTANCE - 10
PERSONNAGES/ENNEMIS - 9

QUALITÉ SONORE - 9
QUALITÉ INTELLIGENCE ARTFICIELLE - 8.5
FACTEUR REJOUABILITÉ - 7.5
FACTEUR DIFFICULTÉ - 7
FACTEUR INNOVATION - 8.5"

reviewText:
A massively under-rated game. I would recommend this game to anyone! I picked it up in a sale and haven't regretted it. I haven't been brave enough to try it on hard yet but standard difficulty is challenging enough without it becoming to stressful- trying to get to all of your buildings in time to protect them.

A really good range of enemies and defenses, I would have liked some better weapons, you don't really need any other axe than the first one. I liked the levelling system, as you can't purchase every perk it makes you personalise your character to your style of play.

10/10

reviewText:
A game that surprised me in more than one way. With a good story, nice atmosphere , offering a lot of ways to survive each night and adding a RPG skill tree for your character to evolve when enough experience is accumulated, Sang-Froid Tales of Werewolves was indeed a worthwhile experience.
I took my time with this game, and played with Jack (higher difficulty) and it proved to be challenging.
You must be careful how you spend your action points each day and your money, so planning is the key action here. Taking on the werewolves, wolves, windigos, fire demons on your own without traps is not reccomended.
If you want something quite interesting to play that will keep your mind busy with setting traps as well as being cunning in combat, this is the game for you.
(you also get bonus points on enjoying this game if you like werewolves, wolves in particular!! )
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText: I am absolutely amazed by the love of detail in this game. The music, the entire artwork with the interfaces and such, it is just incredible. Also the story is well written and the skill tree gives room for different playstyles. Sure, the graphics could be better and combat could feel a little more smooth, but it is not supposed to be a DmC or anything like that. It is a rather strategic game, that favors resource management even in combat. Another thing I want to point out is the amount of time they put into explaining everything with ingame tutorial videos, you will never feel like you missed something. This game is highly recommended to anyone that wants something out of the box, I love it!

reviewText: Brilliant concept, I enjoy how this game addresses how one could face off against multiple opponents through the use of intimidation. However, I do not recommend you get this game because the execution of this one great idea is poor and is not focused upon. Most of the time you will be running between control points babysitting them.\n\nReally wanted more from this gameplay, very sad. Oh and the rest of the game (cinematics, RPG elements) is laughable. To the creators I'd say fantastic job on trying to do something new, I never found a bug or a readily abusable exploit. A game I would love is in here but too much running from point A to point B to guard buildings made of wet tissue paper.

reviewText:
Sang-froid is a great game, in concept! The translation of the idea into a videogame is also done well, mechanics-wise.
The big problem, for me, is how unpolished and frustrating the execution has been, especially for a 15€ game.

The game feels dated in almost every respect. Graphics, story-telling, how the combat and guns work, transitions, item system, etc. etc. Everything is very imperfect and takes way more time than it should.
I don't want to make a full blown review, so I'll try to very briefly state the most glaring problems.

I've played the game twice. Once on Easy Mode, once on Hard Mode. Easy Mode was very uninteresting. Combat over strategy. Hard Mode was infuriating, since, while strategy was the focus, the combat was still very much required to a great degree, while your character was clearly very underpowered. As a result, almost every mission required multiple tries, even after I had the strategy laid and should have worked. I completely ignored the story and all of the other aspects aside from mechanics in the second playthrough.

Why? Because it's terrible. Honestly. The story is fairly cool, especially since I do like fairy-tale and folk stories, in general. The problem is how the story is delivered. It's... mind boggling to me. The story is told exclusively through cutscenes" that are merely characters talking to one another. Nothing fancy. The problems are: the writing isn't good
date: coupled with horrible voice-acting. I don't think the actors were in the same room at all. Each line feels completely disconnected from the situation at hand
recommended: and the tone is completely off. It just doesn't deliver.\nThen
hoursPlayed: there's the fact that
helpfulPercent: they use some pretty bad 3D models
votesHelpful: just because. The animations aren't all that great either. Nothing justifies the choice for these "cutscenes". A simple 2D conversation
votesTotal: with little animation and no voice-acting could have been much more polished without half of the work.\nNot to mention that this had nothing to do with the game. Yet
votesFunny: it's one of the main elements of the product
commentsCount: and it sticks out like a sore thumb.\n\nIt's really

column18: if it was a new idea
column19: or something. This brings nothing new
column20: nothing impressive. On the contrary

column30: but some of them are mostly useless or situational.\nStill

reviewText:
The basic gameplay is pretty good but the pacing is terrible. I doubt the developers played through their own tutorial. You get a short video when a decent item description would have done the job. Rather than encouraging players to explore, the game assumes the player is a ♥♥♥♥♥ and tells you exactly what to do, step by step for the first 3 levels. That is in addition to the pop-up tutorials every 20 feet. If you think the gamers will be too stupid to figure out your game, maybe the solution is to make the mechanic more intuitive, not have 2 dozen videos explaining various concepts peppered in waypoints.

The game does get more challenging and fun later on but the interface remains clunky. The game is plagued with interface issues: you can undo traps but not work, the hud favors artistic flare to actually providing information (health bar most guilty), you have to navigate through a half dozen buildings in town for upgrades and items, even though it could have easily all been fit into a single interface.

The game lauds it's exciting and epic story. Yet aside from an awesome opening cinematic, the game chooses to tell the story in laughable animations. They are poorly dialogued, occur much too frequently and worse, doesn't inform or drive gameplay at all. They break up the pacing of the game and most of the characters are one dimensional. Instead of a handful (yes more than 1) of animations every level, a cinematic every 5 would have been amazing.

I bought Sangfroid expecting an exciting indie game with fresh gameplay. The gameplay mechanics are pretty interesting, maybe even enough so to be called unique and exciting. But the rest of the game feels just like the bloated mess out of major studios. If this is an indie game, it most certainly doesn't feel like one. Gameplay was the coin spent to purchase all the frills in the game.

reviewText:
Ultimately this game was well thought, and put together. Although if they had just put some extra time to fix the minor things could have been much better. When I first start the game, it takes about 1-2 minutes to get past the load screen when I have 200 fps. Now, I'd be more okay with sitting in a load screen for 1-2 minutes if there was actually something going on, or had better music. It plays the same sound track that is about 20-30 seconds long on loop till you get past the load screen. Then you jump straight into a cut scene that doesn't make much sense till you play the more of the game. Although if you don't take the time to play the game you won't find out why they threw a random cut scene in your face. Warning, when werewolves come they're loud as all hell can get. I have my setting on low for sound effects and music and my computer volume at 5 and it sounds as if there was a actual wolf howling in my ear. That ♥♥♥♥ is loud.

You get about 2 charaters that you can pick from, either are large burly man or a smaller man. They show a girl, that at first I thought you could play, but when I hovered over her, I couldn't. Now, I haven't played very much of the game, so maybe later in the game you can play the charater later on.

Cut scenes from what I have seen I am not pleased with. I hear 2 different pitches from just being in a regular game, to a cut scene the voice can have a different pitch or almost sound completely different. From seeing the first cut scene within the first few seconds I expected lips to move at least. If you look close enough, sure you can see 100 pixels move, but it doesn't look like a lip is actually move, but just glitching. They show other larger things moving in the cut scene, but what I couldn't understand is not a simple lip movement?

There was a very small story from what I was getting at. The usual werewolves are destroying farms etc. So, I would strongly reccomend against buying this game for the story line, because it's mainly a tower defense game.

The actual gameplay it's self is very well put together. Will I be playing more of this game, probably. The way they did the traps, was some what acurate, but well thought for the game, so that wolves don't just go HAH ♥♥♥♥ YOUR TRAP". They also didn't make the traps insanly over powered. Now
date: there are different leveled wolves which makes the game more interesting and makes you think more about how to place things
recommended: because if you place things in then wrong spot you can lose the night. The game is pretty much a 3rd Person

reviewText:
Amazing.
Love the different aspects of theis game, the developers realy make you think about how you are going to plan the traps for the night to give you an edge over the monsters.
And i love the fact that they make you pay dearly if you have misplaced a trap or a bait and you will have to mak do with your axe.
Also making the main character waeker than the enimies is a great idea it realy makes you think that if you have to use hand to hand combat (or in this instance, axe to claw) you have to use every thing you can to get an advantag, from using your musket, making an attmept with your axe, or even luring your enemies to a trap that hasent been used.

Also I love that you realy have to use anything to put distance between an army of werewolves and yourself and bonfires are the best to do so, because if you think that if just yur axe will get you through the night your are wrong.

And having the buildins to protect is a great idea it makes the night less about making sure that the character lives and more about making sure the builds survive.

All in all Sang Froid Tales Of Werewolves" one of the best stratagies/action games I have ever played.
Hope they release a sequal

reviewText:
This is a very original mashup of several different genres - a tower defender, an rpg and a TPP masher to name a few. If I had to name one game that is similiar to this one it would probably be Orcs Must Die!, but it is still very very different.

Sang-Froid's setting is enough to make it stand out from the rest. The story being told takes us back to the times where the northern american settlers lived aside native indians. The player plunges into the role of one of the two O'Carroll brothers, forced to fight for the life of their ill sister and their own as well.

Game consists of two distinct parts - the 'tactical' phase, taking place at dawn and the 'action' phase where our tactical plan is being put to test. Would you expect Orcs Must Die ! clone, you'd be up for a big suprise, a selection of deadly machines that chew, chop and incinerate mindless hordes of enemies is replaced by simplistic traps, overhang nets filled with stones and baits that only slow down your enemies. Most of the traps are disposed after being used and aside from a handful barely useful tools, they require to be set off manually with a painfully slow reloading rifle.

Well, the game is difficult. An easy setting (represented by Joe, the burly O'Caroll brother) turns out to be nowhere near easy. On the other hand failure comes free-of-charge and you can repeat and rethink your tactics infinitely, as long as you're not satisfied with the success. There's nothing cheap about the challenge, not Borderlands 2 half-♥♥♥♥♥ design or numbers ridicule. It takes a bit of thought to survive each night, but it's both satisfying and rewarding once you make it.

Obviously the game is not perfect. A little rough round the edges, some animations could be a tad more refined and so on - but that's nothing you wouldn't expect from an indie game coming from a very small studio. My biggest gripe is the awful voice acting which does nothing but hinders the story told. I'd glad with no va at all, in favour of the subtitles, unfortunately the option isn't there. On the other hand the folkish score is loveable and really adds to an already great package.

Bottom line: buy it, these guys deserve your support. It's definitely worth it's current price-tag and getting it on sale is a no-brainer.

reviewText: Sang-Froid - Tales of Werewolves combines tower defense with wilderness survival horror and a little resource management/trade, and achieves this hefty little combo with style and panache.\nThere are some truly original mechanics in the game, such as the fear factor" that pits your own character's fear (or bravado) against that of the blood-hungry beasts of the night - when the werewolves pluck up enough courage
date: they will attack; this passing of time is represented by a meter on the HUD.  This mechanic can create some really tense moments as you frantically struggle to reload your flintlock rifle
recommended: or try to get away to a well booby-trapped spot on the farm before the hairy hordes close in for the kill.\nFrom historically accurate weapons and equipment to an easy to access resource management element
hoursPlayed: there is plenty to keep the player engrossed in many hours of werewolf bashing.  Oh
voteText: and did I mention this game has possibly one of the best (and most fitting) soundtracks I've heard?  Great fun

I'd like to recommend this game to people that love supernatural stories like I do.
Gameplay is pretty nice, it was fun for me to plan how you want to handle each day by laying traps first. And after that it's showtime. Things can go wrong, but it is pretty fun to change your tactics for better results or when things go wrong.
And there is that one good song that got stuck in my head, love it when that song plays when you are beating the wolves.
So my opinion is that Sang-Froid -Tales of Werewolves is a good game and I can't wait to see more.

reviewText: I am so pleased that I got this game greenlit, it's a amazing game. You play as one of the O'caroll brothers who ends up defending their sister from werewolves. In this game, the story of these werewolves and wolves is that they are under the control of the devil. Werewolves are created from souls of sinners that are expelled as they sleep and then merge into a wolf, creating the humanoid wolves you fight, but there are a range of other creatures to fight which have their own weaknesses and strengths in reguards to how traps effect them, in lures work and what might do more damage.\n\nThe story is very good and the switching between axes (holy for one type, silver for others) and preparing traps makes the stategy all the more interesting. There are also three types of bullets. normal, holy and silver which have their uses, however the rifles they use are old fashioned musket rifles so you will need to make sure that one shot counts and kills whatever you are shooting at. The only things that let it down is it suffers from Brutal Legend's idea of replaying missions where if you do it, you erase all data of the missions you completed after that and so you can potentially farm xp or cash to help you in the final battle or just to improve yourself in the events, however unlike Brutal Legend you are given a clear warning before doing this. Buy this as soon as possible, I highly recommend it!

reviewText:
This is a really interesting game. As an action tower defense game you can't avoid comparing Sang-Froid to Orcs Must Die. However, these games are very different in gameplay and layout. In Sang-Froid you prepare all your traps before starting the level in contrast to OMD where you start the level and then place traps. In that manner Sang-Froid is a little more slow paced and not quite hectic as OMD, but enough with the comparison. Let's focus on Sang-Froid alone.

The story isn't the strongest side of Sang-Froid and the same could be said about the voice acting and cut-scenes. On the contrary the music is really great and it's a perfect fit for the game. The surroundings and the environment also suits this game nicely. I really like the cold, snowy lumberjack theme. The game evolves around one single map which you play every mission. It could let you to believe it would get boring quickly, but the map changes enough along with the objectives that it doesn't feel boring.

The traps offer a good variety of different killing possibilities. You can upgrade weapons and traps for the fur you sell after killing wolves or werewolves. You could also buy potions and other useful item between each level.

What I would like to have seen is that when you play the game the second time with the other brother you know all traps, how the map works etc. but you have to listen to how to use the traps again. It would have been nice to have these things unlocked after you beat the game once. Also, a co-op mode would have been a nice feature. Perhaps in a sequel? Or as the story in this game turn out, a prequel would be more fitting...

All in all, I thoroughly enjoyed this game and it was well worth the money.

reviewText:
Let me start this off by saying that I REALLY wanted to enjoy this game; Sang Froid features an original and interesting idea, but is marred by plain out lazy execution.

The first serious problem you will encounter in this game is the terrible pacing. It starts you off in a child-like hand holding tutorial which you must suffer through. The tutorial is explained by an older gentleman in segmented videos. This format leaves absolutely no room for learning or experimentation. The hand holding doesn't stop with the tutorial vidoes either; through out the game you are constantly bombarded by annoying pop ups containing tips.

Another problem, although small, and perhaps unimportant to some, is the poor voice acting, which is painfully apparent. This is honestly some of the worst voice acting I've ever encountered. The acting and dialogue feels incredibly forced and not fluid at all. This lack of fluidity also applies to the cutscenes and animations. The combination of all this makes it impossible for me to be invested in the story.

I was expecting the saving grace for this game to be the combat, unforunately, the combat is actually shallow and uneventful. With the assisted aiming and large packs of enemies, fighting foes turns into a mouse clicking fest in which you will find yourself monotonously smashing the attack button. There is a fear" mechanic which is meant to play in with the stamina feature. Enemies have a "fear" meter that slowly builds. Upon reaching a certain point of fear
date: the animal will then attack. In the time spent waiting for an animal's fear to rise to an attacking point
recommended: you'll have time to reload your rifle and let your stamina regenerate. So by the time the enemy comes to attack
hoursPlayed: you're already fully loaded and prepared
voteText: which really dictates the pace of fighting into an almost turn based setting. I have no qualms with the day time planning strategizing portion of the combat.\n\nWhen you combine all these problems with the unintersting and sporadic story
helpfulPercent: you feel left with a half-♥♥♥♥♥ game with poor atmosphere.\n\nUltimately
votesHelpful: I can only reccomend this game to children
votesTotal: or perhaps even first time gamers who need generous doses of help and guiding."

reviewText:
I really want to like this game as the presentation and story are really great and want to draw me in but unfortunately the poor pacing and slow trial and error gameplay really shatter my interest in this title.

The UI, the way the story is told and the writing itself is very cozy. It really makes an interesting universe until you actually do start controlling your chosen character then it really goes down hill.

Gameplay comes down to building defenses and then defending the buildings your supposed to. Early on this isn't so bad until you start hitting 3 or more buildings where you have to defend them all and they are all vastly far from eachother and in the event of one being destroyed you lose so you end up having to do a bit of multi tasking in order to keep everything together and this can require trial and error as you figure out what will work and what wont for each mission.

The combat though is very floaty and dousn't feel very solid. If I didn't know better I would think you weren't actually supposed to go into direct combat with enemies since it feels very poor when compared to the presentation quality of the rest of the game. Its clunky and at times it can be difficult to hit enemies with your melee attack and in the process get hit yourself. Some of the aspects like fear and rage are very interesting but unfortunately managing these aspects on top of the combat on top of defending your buildings isn't really fun after a time as you battle with the clunkiness while trying to do everything before one of your buildings die.

The pacing really becomes a problem at the point where the game becomes challenging as it gets so slow that the high points are not high enough to actually make it worth it.

So maybe I will someday play more of Sang Froid but for now I really have no impetus to play more of it and would rather just like to see the story play out but not enough to actually beat the game.

Also for as basic as the graphics are its very poorly optimized. Many basic video settings such as windowed mode are not supported either. So once you start peeling back the facade the lack of structure shows. As an analogy I think that fits this game at where I am in it.

reviewerDisplayName: Not Here for Fortune or Fame
reviewText: I could talk about how the mandatory auto-aim often picks targets that aren't what you're pointing your musket at. I could talk about how the traps in this trap-based tower defense style game often have iffy collision detection. I could even talk about how the game has awful framerate and lag issues despite not looking very good at all, making anything that requires even the slightest bit of precision feel entirely luck-based.\n\nBut I suspect that you have better things to do with your time than to read the rants of a complete stranger on the internet, let alone playing a game that despite a unique premise and a refreshingly Canadian" theme manages to be an nearly unplayable mess."

reviewText:
It's aboot time I did this here review eh.

Well I tried this here game a coople months ago and got pretty bored quickly I might say, its got alright gameplay but feels very gritty and old, like something from 2002 or someting'. Read this here like as if you lived in newfoundland or newbunswick b'y.

I can't say I would git dis her game I tell ya, shes too bland and boring in my opinion b'y.

Old gritty graphics that are outdated and not even enjoyable in that way, nothing positive about that. The gameplay is slightly boring and just bleh. You will deal with just a mess of monsters coming from every direction you can think of, up, down, left, right, rileft, up der b'y.

Has a nice talent tree with good customization and plenty of traps and weapons to play with, giving you a decent toolshed of death to kill native werewolfs and the devils monsters. You can go to town and buy more bullets for your musket, dip your axe in holy water to deal extra damage, buy alcohols or clothing to help your defense and offense and use unique items to change the winds path or other fun stuff.

Its simple, easy to pick up and has a decent tutorial to teach you what the hell is going on, but it just was not for me and I say look up the screenshots and maybe check out a video or two, I got it on sale for 2$ CANADIAN so I won't hurt too much up here in the north.

Personal Rating: 2/5

reviewText:
Sang-Froid, is a strange game. It is a mix of tower / trap defence that is very similar to orcs must die! However, this is a poor copy of the latter. It is clunky and buggy with very little room for personal choice. While the game gives you options in terms of traps, it does not in the way you use them if you wish to win.

Some good features are the story, the music and the art style which is quite quirky and fun.
The bad is that there is little to no freedom for the player and the game is quite buggy.

In this case I would not recomend the game unless it is on sale and you have a lot of patience.

Ticklepants

reviewText: A first person tower defense game like sanctum or orcs must die.  The setting and idea is awesome but it's a pretty amateurish effort, the metacritic score is incredibly generous.  The movement and combat are clunky, you move, swing, & turn like a slug.  The interface has way too much going on with all kinds of silly little extra mechanics to pile onto the basic uncompelling gameplay.  Animations are stiff and jerky, sounds are generic and repetitive. The voice acting is so unprofessional it sounds like the devs got a bunch of their friends together some weekend in a studio to read some lines they were just handed.\n\n

reviewText:
Meh...
I know I haven't played this game much, but it hasn't given me any reason to play it more.

The main frustration with this game is that it has a lot of cool and unique gameplay nuances, but unfortunately, the nuances of the gameplay can't redeem the gameplay as a whole.  I know that sounds odd but hear me out.  Imagine going to a restaurant.  They have the most amazing lemonade, but the rest of the food blows.  Does it make for a good restaurant?

The combat gets old quickly and the graphics are almost hard to look at.  Not that the graphics are necessarily bad, but they are just kind of awkward, like a bad PS2 game thats trying to be somewhat realistic, but just ends up looking goofy.  The story is somewhat unique, but isn't prevalent enough to make a difference.

All in all, this game is more laughable than it is an intense werewolf game.  If you want to try it, wait for it to be on sale for dirt cheap, but don't pay more than $3 for this game.

reviewText:
Sang-Froid is a hybrid 3rd person action / tower defense game that excels at neither. In fact, both elements are constantly tripping the other up.

Basic premise: You defend various buildings against monster (mostly wolves and werewolves during the night, and build/upgrade during the day. You kill monsters with both traps and your axe/musket.

On the surface it's a great idea for a game. You're trapped in spooky isolated woods and during the day you have to spend your limited time choosing how to survive the coming sunset.

Why it fails is because the 3rd person movement and controls are so sluggish, the map is far too spread out, and the majority of the traps require you to be present in order to take effect but you can't be everywhere at once.

3rd person action: super clunky melee swings and musket reloading. I realize it's not going to be as fast paced and adreniline pumping as a dedicated action game, but if it's going to be THIS clunky and boring then they should have just ditched it to make this a full on tower defense strategy game. You're not shooting huge guns like Sanctum, you're dealing with clunky axe swinging. There's a system where you have to manage the wolves' fear level; keep them afraid enough so the entire pack doesn't jump you at once. This might have been interesting in a game with better combat, but it's just frustrating because you don't have time to deal with it because your other building are all the way across the map.

Overly large map: The full map (once all locations open up) is larger than most DotA maps and it takes a good 2 minutes to traverse the entire thing. It's way too slow and you have to be everywhere at once. Later on you can build ziplines to travel quicker, but then you have to sit through the slow climbing animations like it's a Zelda game, plus the ziplines cannot go through trees and the whole map in one winding forest. Since it's 3rd person, you can only see what's in sight of your character and have little idea what's happening other than some icons on the map. This is a big problem because...

Non-automated traps: The majority of the traps in the game require you to be present in order to work. You must shoot ropes to drop rocks on wolves. You must light bonfires. You must man turrets. The whole point of traps should be to cover areas you can't be at. If they can't do that then what's the point and why not just make it a full on action game? There are a couple traps that theoretically take care of things when you're not there, but they're unreliable. You can lay down flaming trenches that monsters can't cross, but it's very hard to tell if the trench is completely blocking off a path or if there's one tiny pixel you missed that monsters can pass through, derailing your entire plan and forcing you to start over. Likewise with lethal traps. You can place 3 lethal traps at a chokepoint and sometimes all the monsters will run into them, sometimes none. It's totally random which is the opposite of what a good tower defense game should be.

The story: The devil is summoning monsters to attack you. That's the entire story, but they drag it out with non-animated, horribly acted, boring cutscene after cutscene.


There was a kernal of a good game idea buried in here somewhere. If they were going to make so many traps reliant on you being present, they should have turned it into primarily an action game. If the action was going to suck so much they should have turned it into a pure strategy game. In trying to do both they compromised each other.

reviewText:
Fun game! When I first saw the title I was excited, but then i saw it looked like a hard to learn Strategy game which I rarley play and have time to learn. When I saw it go on sale for 75% off, I decided to give it a try. First thoughts? LOVE IT!
The creators have done a fantastic job at so many aspects of this game.
1.The music and sound design are great.
2.They mix story, strategy with some good hands on fighting and killing of wolves!
3. IN GAME VIDEO TUTORIALS that take you step by step through each aspect of how to play and what each thing does.
They don't just leave you hanging, they take you thorugh several games and mission with a video showing what you need to know, how to do it, and then let you try it. These aren't just static images. These are fully voiced and animated lessons for everything you need to know! So if you are like me and have a hard time figuring all the features out, no need to worry! They teach you everything.

4 STARS! Great game.

reviewText:
As an opening to my review I would like to point out that, unlike some other publishers out there, Artifice Studio respect the Steam community and it's trader users, people who invested money in getting multiple copies of the game at a certain discounted price for trading purpose (by trading games for items we often can get our hands on other games for a fraction of the price even if already heavily discounted from other steam users who have those games) and, it would seem, they respect* that we didn't spent the money simply to see the same deal occur the next year during the anual summer/winter event and that is a good thing.

*Last time Sang Froids was discounted at 90% and, right now at the time of this review during the summer event of 2015, it is 80% off and the few of us who got the game at the most advantageous price can trade with more ease compared with the games that have the same discount price showing up event after event making it difficult to make even the slightest profit from these games.

You're welcomed to leave comments on this review about this subject to help us build a better trading community. On with the review now...

-----------------------------------------------

The game itself is pretty unique as you have hack and slash battles and first person shooter elements combined with some tower defence aspects like traps and buildings that you must defend from the invaders and lots of upgradeable abilities thrown in for good measure. The music and voice acting compliment the game ambiance in all the tongues available. The story is created in part by Bryan Perro who is famous around here in Quebec.

In short you shoot werewolves after luring them under and around all sorts of traps that you acquire as you progress into the game and unravel the mystery that surrounds the town of Val-des-loups (Ancient town that no longer exist here in Quebec). Lots of fun, interesting story and good music.

reviewText:
Sang Froid: The Tale of a Double Whammy of Garbage. It is a TD/action game and both aspects are done in a way that suck balls. The melee combat just feels awkward and the TD aspect is boring and not done well compared to other games such as Dungeon Defenders.

I realize this got a 79/100 metacritic average and I even read in the forums someone saying they have 321 hours in it but despite trying to force myself to like this I can't. The first hour of the game is about 30 minutes of tutorials/interruptions, 10 minutes of cutscenes, and 20 minutes of gameplay which is about 5-10 minutes on the planning screen/in town and 10-15 short minutes of actual gameplay. It feels like the whole game is about 50% TD/action and 50% adventure game and adventure games blow. Maybe as you play on and get the five thousand tutorials out of the way, there is more gameplay. The game just has such a bad indie game feel I couldn't stand it long enough to find out. HOW IN GOD'S NAME DID THIS GET A 79 META AVERAGE???

The action game part, melee combat, is imo poorly done. Just feels awkward and clunky. Also, my guy can swing only a few times at a wolf before running out of stamina, like he smokes nine packs of cigarettes a day and has trouble breathing or something. I am out of shape badly and I could swing an axe at wolves for a good long while before I was out of breath. Combat just feels generically done. And mouse control does not feel right either because it A) uses mouse acceleration to spin the camera faster the quicker you move it and B) also does not have sensitivity matched up right on the axis'. X axis (left & right) is fine but Y axis (up & down) is too low and it makes a odd matchup and feels awful, and there are no options in the game to change it. When they can't even make the controls feel normal, that is bad news.

The planning screen where you lay traps looks like crap, and all other menu screens have a crap look and feel about them. Where good games look smooth and crisp in their menu's, this one's presentation value is just sharp, dull, and ugly. That leads to the other part of the game, tower defense mechanics, which suck balls. After laying down traps and nets and stuff, I start and since they are coming from 3 different paths all over the map and the traps don't do anything whatsoever but slow them down slightly, it's like where the fk do I go first? So I pick a spot and go fight a werewolf. While I am doing that, the traps I put down slowed the others only barely so the houses are getting attacked now. The net traps I put down are hard to get anything to go underneath, especially when it says my shout isn't ready yet and I don't even think I used it yet. The wolves usually just walk passed my net trap so it is a waste and I just killed them with the clunky crap balls melee fighting.

If you want a TD/action game that is properly reviewed as a good game, try Dungeon Defenders. If you want a TD/action game that all the reviewers played blindfolded, play this. I mean it honest to God boggles my mind as to how this game got a 79 metacritic average. The melee and TD portions of the game are both a nightmare compared to Dungeon Defenders.

5/10, if that.

For now is a no.
It takes forever to load, packed with animations and intros that you have to deal with every single time you start the game. The game doesnt run smoothly. Combat is goofy.

The concept is nice, I like the theme that made get this, I wouldn't complain as I got it on sale but it isn't anywhere close to worth the full price.

reviewText: I really can't say much about this game. The acting is bad to the point of laughable. Think the old Resident Evil games. The story telling is very confusing, too; at least the part that I got to. It's unoptimized to the point of getting 30 fps on a decent rig (I can get 60 on TF2 at max graphics) and the controls are horrific. The button layout itself isn't the problem, it's the input delay. You press your attack button then 1.5 seconds later, it finally happens. I crashed twice: once during the initial loading screen (that went on for 4 min) and once during gameplay. You know what unplayable games always score? 0/10 It's a shame, too. This was the most impressive greenlight game I had seen at the time and I waited a long time...for this. It's laggy, it's buggy, it crashes like crazy, it's unfinished, and we'll need mods soon, so come on in, Bethesda fans!

reviewText: Amazin game, the nights make you full of fear :) while the battle engine may not be the best on the market, but it has some unique and very interesting ideas, I loved the fear factor. But the best is the strategy part. I can spend an hour planning for the next night , it is just an interesting process by itself.

I'll admit I was very wary of this game when I took my first glimpse in it's direction. While othing seemed mechanicly wrong with the game from the get go, nothing really stood out to me either as anything worthwhile. However with a recent sale, and a good friend of mine recomending it every chance he got, I decided to pick the game of and give it an honest chance

The first thing I'll mention aout the game is that while the combat has a clunky feel to it, it's surprisingly enjoyable and really fits the theme of the game, if theirs any time I found myself frustrated with an outcome in combat it was because I hadn't managed properly and felt the weight of it come crashing down on me. You play one of two lumberjacks fighting the Devil and his werewolf, spirit army. Pretty badass concept but it's up to you to be the badass of the story, the game won't do it for you.

Resource management is key to winning this game, and the trap and resource system is set up harsh but fairly. You really need to pay atention to what your actually able to spend on upgrading your personal gear like weapons, protective clothing and consumables, because while a good axe or rifle may come in handy, they only help you against one or two enemies before your overwhelmed, however a proper trap could take out four enemies in one go, nothing beats a properly executed trap.

The game also has a fear system, allowing you to scare off certain enemies , and help even the odds against the packs of wolves that often surround you. Alot of enjoyment is to be found making your enemies hesitate to atack you and start having to size you up before their confident enough to strike again.

Lastly but cerainly not least is the soundtrack to this game. This game has one of the best soundracks I've ever heard. It definitely has music you can stomp your foot to (I speak from experience on this.) The music of this game brings everything to another lvel, it makes combat even more enoyable, it gives you a goo sense of the world, and it's just plain fun to listen too.

In short Sang-Froid is a challenging but rewarding game that offers fun gameplay, a badass story, and some of the best music you'll ever hear in a video game, if not just in general. I'd recomend this game to anyone who likes a nice challenge and is a fan of strategy. I'd give Sang-Froid an 8/10. It's not the highest budjet game, but you most certainly et your dollars worth for it, most of that with the soundtrack alone.

reviewText: I thought it looked cool, and the narration is wonderful, but the controls are just...blegh. I'm running as if controlling a joystick or on an axis. I simply can't adjust or sidestep to line myself up with my enemies. I'm basically running around and trying to revolve around the wolves in the hopes that whilst in 'mid-orbit' they'll be within reach and I'll be able to kill them.\nIt's also running pretty badly on my laptop, which is sort of understandable, but if it can take Borderlands 2, Pre-Sequel and Dishonored, it should certainly be able to take this game's averagely-rendered graphics.
Very fun, well explained and challenging game. Mix both strategy and action. In sales it's a given jump on that one.

It's a little rough around the edges(especially some of the 3rd person combat at night), but for what it is I'm having a blast with it. Fun to plan out your traps and route during the day and experiment with that for the night time battles. You can tell by the animations in the story that a lot of work didn't go in to that side of it, but the actual story is decent and the gameplay is fun, which is what counts. I recommend it, especially if you happen to find it on sale! 7 out of 10 imo

Here is the most canadian game ever made, and what a joy it is to play.  If you liked Orcs must die, you will probably love this game.  Each day you prapare your battle plan, set up traps, study enemy routes, and spend the rest of your time getting a bit of money for weapons and gear.

Then night falls..  What follows is then a hectic, fast paced dance of blood and steel as you run around activating each part of your plan, seeing it in motion, and hopefully killing your foes before they destroy everything.

This is not an easy game, but when you survive a night by the skin of your teeth, burying your axe into the last enemy, it will be a victory worth cheering.

I just started playing it, but it is really impressive its soundtrack and atmosphere. Also the gameplay is really fun and has elements of action, RPG and strategy (even the action requires a lot of strategy!). Buy this game if you like tower defense and a bit of action!

Its a cool little game & its the first one these developers have made so goodjob so far, i recommend it for all tower defence enthusiasts, its a shame there is no co-op because it would be perfect for this game as there is only two characters to choose from but i can see why they chose not too, the game might be too easy with two people playing... but then again they could have just ramped up the difficulty... who knows, maybe in their next game.

Having picked this up for just a couple dollars during a Steam sale I can honestly say I am not sure if I've ever received this much enjoyment for so little money.

I had spotted the game on Greenlight many months ago and was intrigued by the novel and clever premise for a hybrid strategy/tactics/action. Even then at the 15 dollar mark I was strongly considering the purchase if the game turned out to be good fun. Sadly, the game flew in under my radar on release and I forgot all about it until I noticed it at the top of the User Review list on the Steam sales page.

You play as one of two brothers living in the woods on the outskirts of Wolvesdale, somewhere in Canada. The winters are harsh here and the prowling wolves even harsher. Lil' Jos, the burly big brother is more than capable of whopping wolves with his axe, shooting them with his musket, and setting traps. The other Brother, Jack, is a more frail sort and you will have to lean heavily on your ingenuity with traps to succeed with Jack as your choice.

At the start of the game you are first introduced to Jack and soon thereafter, Jos and their sister Josephine. Josephine has come down with a fever after a travesty at the local church parish involving the pastor. I won't spoil the story for you, as it does a fine job of effortlessly tossing the Christian and pagan at you without being heavy handed or conciously offensive. Christian motifs figure prominently in the story as well as pagan and Native American belief. The characters are well done and push the story along quite well.

Josephine begins to prophecy foreboding events and the two brothers resolve to get her to town for medical treatment. After the nearby bridge has mysteriously burned down, events begin to domino toward ever more sinister happenings. You'll face two varieties of wolves, 2 varieties of werewolves, and a handful of other mythical creatures such as the Amerindian 'Maikan which amounts to their verison of the werewolf myth
date: as well as Will-o-Wisps and the like. The Devil plays a major role and is puppetering the corrupted pastor and townsfolk to play out his wicked game in an attempt to destroy the townsfolk
recommended: the brothers and their sister. The writing is solid and the voice acting is competent. I'm enjoying the cutscenes story unfold into the missions you are tasked with.\n\nThe main game consists of a pre-game tactical strategy map where you purchase and place any number of devious traps to incapacitate and dispose of the hellish fiends. The game has a good learning curve and introduces you to the myriad devices slowly; as it should. This aspect of the game is very reminiscient of the Bullfrog Dungeon Master games of years gone by. Great fun is to be had plotting your tactics to deal with the many waves of enemies that are tasked with destroying your assorted buildings. To write of all the many traps and how to use them would amount to a miniature FAQ and so I will leave much of that to you
hoursPlayed: dear reader
voteText: to research. To say the developers gave you a treasure trove of gadgets is putting it mildly.\n\nAt the beginning of each match you are also able to use the money you acquire from defeating the creatures to purchase better weapons
helpfulPercent: ammo and gear. A coventry nearby can bless your bullets or axes
votesHelpful: respectively
votesTotal: so as to deal greater damage to the diabloical creatures. The general store sells an ever increasing number of muskets that have authentic descriptions of their real world counterparts with some very nifty trivia thrown in. You also can purchase new gear and ammo. And the hotel furnishes you with an assortment of liquors that have varying effects on your character in battle.\n\nDuring the match proper
votesFunny: you will be scurrying as your very life does depend on it. Following the routes you planned during the pre-game phase you will have to be front and center for certain traps to be effective. The deadly net trap requires you to shoot the net and drop it on the creatures below. If you have a bait present under the net you simply take your time and fire. Otherwise
commentsCount: you'll have to get crafty and 'shout' for your enemy to come inspect the area. Bonfires help buff the 'fear factor' that  keeps the creatures at a distance as they prowl slowly around you looking to strike. During this time you can reload your musket and go for the headshot without worrying about being ripped to shreds.  Fire walls can be strategically placed to alter the route of your enemy. Watchtowers with ziplines to other parts of the map are a lifesaver when you need to 'be there' quickly to prevent destruction of your precious buildings. This is only a smattering of the many traps available. Nevermind all the possibilities on how to use them in conjunction with each other.\n\nAnd I haven't even touched on the player levels. Much like an RPG
column16: you earn experience points that allow you to upgrade many traits. Typical character buffs like more health
column17: stamina
column18:
and the like as well as quicker reloading and stronger traps are available. But there are also quite a few unique buffs such as poisoned bait that damages the devouring creature or increasing the damage done as a 'sniper' if you should decide to try for a shot from one of your watchtowers.

I could go on and on about all the neat features of this game with impunity. The game is well balanced and is a blast to play once you grasp the game mechanics. Most of the game elements will feel familiar to the hobby gamer. But by combining them in such a manner requires an enjoyable pause for thought that many modern games no longer ask of you. To have my intelligence and keyboard savvy simultaneously challenged has been a real treat.  The art style is charming and the music very well done. The graphics are rather modest for a modern game and have a World of Warcraft nature to them but serve the game quite well.  Artifice Studio is officially on my list of promising developers to watch.

I cannot recommend this game strongly enough. Especially for the money. A MUST BUY!"

reviewText: One of the most addictive and mold breaking games I played in a while. A breath of fresh air, and the music is amazing :)

Summary of the game (no spoilers). At first, my review was positive, but then I changed my mind. Here is why -


Story 3/5  -> Original, somewhat engaging, but a bit shallow

Graphics 4/5 -> for an action/tower defence game pretty decent

Voice acting/ cinematics 1/5 -> terrible voice acting, but that is not such a big deal. Cinematics are a nusiance.

Gameplay 2/5 -> You want to play. You want to think about the layout of your traps and strategy. But the game will not let you. It is very easy to place the traps, and melee combat is mostly about going near enemy, hitting MB1 (your character will target and hit enemy automatically, even if they are behind you) and sometimes dodging or running away. Shooting would be more fun, but you need to reload every shot which takes way too long for practical purposes and is impossible in melee combat. You can not place traps exactly where you want them, (I am not talking about terrain restriction now), so they happen to be too much to sides for maximizing their potential - and that is just irritating. You also keep XP even from nights you fail, so you are rewarded for failing. It also makes the game less chalenging, which sux.

In-game mechanics and options 5/5 -> there is everything that fits the atmosphere and nothing more that could disturb or overhype it. It is detailed, but not overdone, they put a lot of time into it and they did a good job. It also works quite well, I only saw one or two minor bugs. + they explain the mechanics very well.

Saves and loads mechanics 0/5 -> Daytime starts by cinematics, after that you tend to plant traps for waves of enemies that come at night. There may be 1-6 waves each night. If you screw up even the last wave, you need to start from daytime again (you can relocate the traps) and go again through all the waves. If, however, you decide to turn the game off, it will start with the beginning cinematics of the day the next time you play it, and your traps will be deleted, so you need to place them again. The game loads extremely slowly for such a small game, but the loading song makes up for it.

Fun 3/5 -> This game had great potential. It could have been so much better, perhaps the most complete tower defence / action game hybrid ever made. After a few rounds (when my review was positive) I had great expectations and was looking forward to playing this game. But as I played, it was becoming somehow irritating because of the factors mention above. Still, it was a decent game.

Shoul you buy it? No. It is definitely not worth the price.

However, If you see it on a sale like -80% or so, then YES, you will not regret it.
Very fun, well explained and challenging game. Mix both strategy and action. In sales it's a given jump on that one.

It's a little rough around the edges(especially some of the 3rd person combat at night), but for what it is I'm having a blast with it. You can tell by the animations in the story that a lot of work didn't go in to that side of it, but the actual story is decent and the gameplay is fun, which is what counts. I recommend it, especially if you happen to find it on sale! 7 out of 10 imo

I am not a fan of tower defense games, but San-Froid is an exception I will play again and again. Less worried about upgrades and harder monster that trundle down set paths the game not only shows you where every enemy will come from and what they will attack, but you can easily change their paths as well as change the entire field with traps and tools. Add to this a cute (if poorly voiced) story involving two lumberjack brothers, a posessed sister, and the Devil and you get a mix of RTS, third person shooter, and Supernatural all rolled into a fun game that is well balanced and easy to figure out.

Sang-Froid is one the of most disappointing games that I've played. I went into it thinking that it would be like Orcs Must Die but with werewolves, which sounded like a pretty awesome premise; instead, it turned out to be a clunky, dull action game with strategy and RPG overtones.

The worst part of the game for me is the interface. The font used was definitely picked for style rather than legibility, making it tricky to get a quick read on your ammo count. The health bar is a strange, bifurcated heart which again is not helpful for at-a-glance info. You wield two weapons, but instead of using a toggle, weapon selection is modal. You have to hold down a key to keep the rifle out. Reloading the rifle is boosted by button mashing which is an egregiously stupid mechanic. The whole town's worth of shops could have been condensed into a single screen. The fear factor UI is painfully unintuitive but works decently once explained. I think even the developers realised how bad the UI is because the tutorial is filled with videos describing in elaborate detail how everything works. When you've gotten to that step, you need to seriously rethink your design decisions.

The gameplay is where things really fell apart. It seems like most traps are one-use-only which kills the tower defence feeling for me. Because you can't rely on traps, you need to dispatch a good chunk of the enemies yourself. Unfortunately the lumberjack runs quite slowly, hits weakly and reloads his rifle in a period-correct fashion. Combat is a slow and tedious affair with the player's weakness being balanced out by the enemy's reluctance to attack. To top it off, the animations are surprisingly unsatisfying.

Calling the game an epic folktale is a bit disengenuous. The writing is 90s after-school cartoon caliber and the voice acting is pretty wooden. The animations are disappointingly stilted and exacerbate the problem; using static portraits would have been a major improvement. Worst of all, it takes itself way too seriously.

It's possible that the game gets significantly better after spending enough time on it. Unfortunately, there are plenty of other games that are better right off the bat.

reviewText: Really enjoyed the mix of set-up strategy and in action tactical aspects to this game.  Just ensure that your pc/laptop can fully support it.  Otherwise it doesn't scale down well and the low frame rates make it almost impossible to play.  I say almost as you'll know that you nearly beat that wave/level the last time even with the frame rate issue.  So a minor adjustment to your traps, load out or last level up skill selection would...  It extends the game a lot.

I admit, the game looks a little rough around the edges, but it's a phenomenal take on tower defense games .The cutscenes are a little cheesy, the graphics aren't all that great, but the gameplay is unparalleled. Each 'mission' you have a set amount of money to spend on traps... the more efficient you are at not wasting money, the more money you can spend on better gear/upgrades/etc. This creates a sort of minimalist approach.. you're constantly trying to place as little traps as possible, and setting up a perfect wave by wave traps and backup plans that you can fall back on if something doesn't hit. The feeling of satisfaction you get when you pull of a perfectly planned 5+ wave defense is like nothing I've felt before in a game. Even when something goes amiss and you manage to pull through by the skin of your teeth.. it's great. There's enough RPG skill tree mechanics and 3rd person fighting skill to make it a lot more 'alive' then your normal TD game, too. Buy it! You won't regret it.

Tower-defense/action hybrids have appeared to become a genre on their own.  Games like Orcs Must Die and Sanctum seem to lead the pack in this realm but Sang-Froid has emerged to be my favorite of this style of game.  First off, I love the aesthetic of the game.  The frozen Canadian frontier in December during the 1800s really appealed to me.  Couple this with the werewolf and Native American lore and I was hooked.  There is story here.  The voice acting and animation definitely show it's indie roots (meaning not that great) but unlike other games of this ilk, I actually paid attention to the narrative.\n\nGameplay wise, strategy is key.  Know where to place your traps and what kind of traps to use is crucial.  The planning phase of this game ended up being more instrumental to me than any other tower defense game.  It was extremely satisfying during missions to here a trap go off somewhere in the distance and know I had a kill.  The combat might be the weakest part of this game.  You could say it was challenging" but at times it just seemed clumsy.  I would often swing my ax at an enemy and get caught in a combat animation that would leave me vulnerable.  I don't know if this was intentional but it felt frustrating at times.  However
hoursPlayed: good atmosphere
helpfulPercent: interesting enemies.\nCons:  Clumsy combat
votesHelpful: somewhat stiff voice acting.\n\nI would reccommend this game.  Extra reccommendation: play it in the winter when there is snow on the ground outside  if you can.  This definetly added to my enjoyment of the game."

Summary of the game (no spoilers). At first, my review was positive, but then I changed my mind. Here is why -


Story 3/5  -> Original, somewhat engaging, but a bit shallow

Graphics 4/5 -> for an action/tower defence game pretty decent

Voice acting/ cinematics 1/5 -> terrible voice acting, but that is not such a big deal. Cinematics are a nusiance.

Gameplay 2/5 -> You want to play. You want to think about the layout of your traps and strategy. But the game will not let you. It is very easy to place the traps, and melee combat is mostly about going near enemy, hitting MB1 (your character will target and hit enemy automatically, even if they are behind you) and sometimes dodging or running away. Shooting would be more fun, but you need to reload every shot which takes way too long for practical purposes and is impossible in melee combat. You can not place traps exactly where you want them, (I am not talking about terrain restriction now), so they happen to be too much to sides for maximizing their potential - and that is just irritating. You also keep XP even from nights you fail, so you are rewarded for failing. It also makes the game less chalenging, which sux.

In-game mechanics and options 5/5 -> there is everything that fits the atmosphere and nothing more that could disturb or overhype it. It is detailed, but not overdone, they put a lot of time into it and they did a good job. It also works quite well, I only saw one or two minor bugs. + they explain the mechanics very well.

Saves and loads mechanics 0/5 -> Daytime starts by cinematics, after that you tend to plant traps for waves of enemies that come at night. There may be 1-6 waves each night. If you screw up even the last wave, you need to start from daytime again (you can relocate the traps) and go again through all the waves. If, however, you decide to turn the game off, it will start with the beginning cinematics of the day the next time you play it, and your traps will be deleted, so you need to place them again. The game loads extremely slowly for such a small game, but the loading song makes up for it.

Fun 3/5 -> This game had great potential. It could have been so much better, perhaps the most complete tower defence / action game hybrid ever made. After a few rounds (when my review was positive) I had great expectations and was looking forward to playing this game. But as I played, it was becoming somehow irritating because of the factors mention above. Still, it was a decent game.

Shoul you buy it? No. It is definitely not worth the price.

However, If you see it on a sale like -80% or so, then YES, you will not regret it.

DISCLAIMER: This is a first impressions review, and NOT a full review, if you want a full review, then please read better reviews then mine
